section.title: Communication, Radio, and Destination Sign System
section.para: The NJ Transit Communication, Radio, and Destination Sign System (CRDSS) is designed to operate in a train of a maximum of 10 cars. The functionality of CRDSS equipment installed in the multi-level commuter passenger cars differs by car type, as described following table.

section.title: Train Level Interfaces
section.para: The NJ Transit Door & Communication Trainline (DCTL) and WorldFIP Data Train Network (DTN) are used by the CRDSS to interface within the multi-level cars and with older NJ Transit fleets for all train-level communications. The CRDSS is compatible with the Comet V car’s DTN for digital operations and with the DCTL for baseband analog and discrete operations specifications. The DCTL combines analog audio lines, a LonWorks digital network, and a discrete trainline, whereas the DTN, more specifically the WorldFIP DTN, regroups both digital audio channels and digital data in the redundant WorldFIP digital networks.
Figure shows the train-level interfaces of the CRDSS.

The CRDSS can be interconnected with all NJ Transit cars compatible with either the DCTL or the DTN WorldFIP networks. The following paragraphs describe both the DCTL and the DTN, give the possible train topologies compatible with the CRDSS, and explain the limitations of the older generations of NJ Transit fleets with the multi-level CRDSS functions.

section.title: DCTL Interface Description
section.para: The DCTL, a 27 wire trainline, is a combination of PA/IC baseband audio lines, discrete PA control trainline, and a LonWorks digital network superimposed on the IC baseband audio line through a LonWorks PLT-10A Power Line Transceiver. This LonWorks network constitutes a Communication Control Network (CCN), considering it carries control messages such as “Station ID”, “Special Message ID”, “Public ID”, “Pager” string, and “ODK Lock” state.
Of the 27 wires of the DCTL, the wires used by the CRDSS are presented in the following table.

Both the PA audio lines and the PA discrete control line are used to broadcast a manual PA throughout the train. Prerecorded digital audio files are broadcasted on this same PA audio line from the audio master. Only CCUs on multi-level C Cars hold an instance of the voice database for playback. However, all CCUs (that is, CCUs on any multi-level car) hold an instance of the voice database for interchangeability between different car types. The triggering of the message is performed on the CCN instead of the PA control line. This allows an upcoming manual PA to interrupt the playback of a digital audio message using the PA control line.
The IC audio line is used for the point-to-point audio connection between two operator panels (CCCP or CCP).

The CCN is used for various controls such as train Identification (ID) heartbeat, station announcement ID, special and public message ID, PEI message, and pager messages. It is also used for operator access control, PAA muting, PA car number, and PEI control.

When a destination sign database message (such as a station announcement, a special message, or a public message) needs to be broadcasted, the message ID is transmitted on the CCN and received by every CCU. With their local destination sign database, every CCU searches for the corresponding text message and displays it on its IMS. As indicated above, the prerecorded audio file associated to the destination sign database message is then played back on the PA audio line.

section.title: DTN (WorldFIP Communication Network) Interface Description
section.para: The DTN is a redundant WorldFIP digital network consisting of two pairs of twisted shielded wires. The CCU operates on the DTN when no DCTL type cars are part of the train. The DTN network is used on the Comet V cars, and on the C Car, S Car, and T Car CCUs of the multi-level cars that are interoperable with the Comet V cars.
The DTN WorldFIP communication network pin assignment is presented in the following table.

Periodic network variables are used to transfer the states of such operator panels as the CCP and the Cab Communication Control Panel. The periodic network variables are also used to transfer network states such as DTN/Non-DTN mode and prerecorded message broadcast.

section.title: DTN (WorldFIP Communication Network) Reconfiguration
section.para: Normally, the Fieldbus Internet Protocol (FIP) network cannot reconfigure itself on-the-fly. A car has no means to detect which other car is connected next to it. Thus, modifications have been made to the physical layer in order to implement network topology changes.

First, each car is capable of generating and detecting fritting currents. Being able to detect different fritting polarity (either positive, zero, or negative), each car is capable of knowing if it has a neighbor or not. Next, a special signature has been added at the end of each frame. This signature contains the address of the last car that transmitted the frame. Since each frame must be repeated from one car to the other, this provides a way for a car to know the address of its closest neighbor.
Network configuration is as follows:

list-item.para: Initially, the network is in inauguration phase. In this phase, each car receives a unique address. The network then goes into operational phase.
After this period, if a car detects a fritting current change, it pulls the whole network back again into inauguration phase, effectively reconfiguring the network.
In the operational phase, a car is elected audio master. The audio master controls all accesses to the digital audio system.

section.title: DTN (WorldFIP Communication Network) Digital Audio System
section.para: The purpose of the digital audio system is to provide the following three audio service types:

The digital audio system is an application that runs on each car separately. The car elected audio master must also run an additional control application. When an audio master, the car controls all the resources needed to communicate on a channel. These resources include peripheral panel microphones, peripheral panel speakers, and network bandwidth. Cars must always be authorized by the audio master before sending or receiving audio.

section.title: CRDSS Car Level Interfaces
section.para: On a car level basis, the CRDSS interchanges information with the Car Level Diagnostic System (CLDS), the cab control circuitry, and the display signs (FDS, SDS, and IMS). (See Figure .)
The CLDS and the CRDSS exchange information primarily for diagnosis purposes, pre-recorded message control, and MDU display control.

The CRDSS interfaces with a cab makeup relay contact from the cab circuitry to activate the CCCP when the master controller key is inserted. The CCCP also interfaces with the cab Master Door Control Panel, which allows the operator to activate the CCCP without activating the cab with the master controller key. The CCCP also interfaces with the Alerter/Indicator System, which informs the ASES that the operator has been active with a cab control. Additionally, the CRDSS has six discrete inputs activated by the Door Control Units (DCU) for door closing trigger signals used to activate the interior and exterior door chime.

Even though the CRDSS includes all the display signs, it needs to communicate with them on the Data Car Network (DCN). All control commands are sent to the signs on the DCN without any feedback from the sign. The status of every signs is sent to the CLDS for display.

section.title: CRDSS Peripheral Interfaces
section.para: The CCU is the main processing platform of the CRDSS. It manages all communications, and thus interfaces with most of the CRDSS peripherals; for this reason, it is not considered a peripheral.
The following table regroups the peripherals, the interface types, and the equipment to be interfaced.

row.entry: Audio control network (RS-485) and individual audio lines
Audio control network (RS-485) and individual audio lines
Audio control network (RS-485) shared audio lines
Noise sensing microphones Automatic Output Level Adjustment (AOLA)

section.para: Figure shows the interfaces for C Car types (the S Car and T Car support only a subset of those interfaces). They also include the train level interfaces to give an overall picture of the CRDSS. The cab circuitry discrete signals and Alerter/Indicator System discrete signals collected by the CCCP are not shown in the figure.

As indicated earlier, the diagnosis related information such as the operational status variable, the Real-Time Data Monitoring (RTDM) frames, the file request and software updates, the time set command and the software versions request are defined in the supplied documents. All traffic required to control the pre-recorded message such as messages ID (station, special, and public messages), sign control, and monitoring and MDU locking.

The Audio Control Network (ACN) is implemented by using J1708 transceivers. J1708 is based on the RS-485 physical layer. The ACN uses the J1708 transport and data layer. The ACN is used in a master/slave approach as specified in the J1708 specification. The CCU is always the network master, whereas the CCCP, CCP, and PEI panels, and the PAA are always the network slaves. Each slave has its own physical address. The CCU initiates a request message by sending a signal to a peripheral; it then waits for a response/acknowledgement signal from the peripheral. If the peripheral does not respond/acknowledge, the CCU times out.

The panel audio lines are used to send and receive PA/IC/PEI baseband voice audio signals between the CCU and the panels. The CCU controls the connections on the audio lines over the ACN as described in the previous paragraph.
Each CCCP and CCP has its own audio line whereas a single line is used for all the PEI panels of a car. The reason for this is that only one PEI call can be processed at a time in the consist.
Each audio line has the following characteristics:

list-item.para: Frequency response: 80 Hz to 8000 Hz (±3 dB)

section.para: The noise sensing audio lines are defined as the Pulse-Width Modulator (PWM) communication lines between the noise sensing microphones located in four PA speaker enclosures and the CCU Audio Control Board (ACB) Circuit Card Assemblies (CCA).

The PTE serial port includes the Receiver (RX) and Transmitter (TX) line with the signal ground, the hardware flow control Request to Send (RTS) and Clear to Send (CTS), a direct connection with the DCN LonWorks and a 74 Vdc Low Voltage Power Supply (LVPS) connection for PTE laptop power supply.

The speaker audio network is defined as the audio link between the PAA and the speakers. This is a 70.7 V system terminated by an audio transformer at the speaker end. The audio transformer has three different power taps as defined in the discussion of the ACN, above.

All CCUs installed in all three car types (cab, trailer, and trailer with toilet) are identical. Two shorting ID discrete inputs of the power supply CCA will allow the CCU application to identify its position.
The CRDSS memory is contained in the CCU. The memory supplied under this contract is provided with spare memory equivalent to 30 percent of the required application.
The CCU requires strapping to identify its location identification. (See Table .)

section.title: CCU Backplane
section.para: The CCU backplane CCA has a 15 DIN-41612 (level 1) socket connector. The backplane provides 3U and 6U card slots. Card-edge connectors are not used. An additional connector is provided for a cable running to the indicator CCA. The top bus is compatible with the CPU CCA bus. The bottom bus provides additional power and I/O lines.
To ensure that CCAs cannot be installed in an incorrect slot, polarizing combs and studs are provided for all backplane connectors. The CCU backplane CCA is labelled CCU BACKPLANE CCA.
The following figure shows the order of CCA installation in the card cage.
The following table presents the card cage layout and connector key positions.

In order to minimize Electromagnetic Interference (EMI) and simplify signal termination, all backplane bus signals are slew-rate limited. This is implemented on all CCAs by driving bus signals using Xilinx Complex Programmable Logic Device (CPLD) slew-rate limited outputs, or by placing small value resistors in series with outputs.

section.title: CCU Power Supply CCA
section.para: The CCU power supply CCA converts the Low Voltage Distribution Network (74 Vdc nominal) power to 10 Vdc ±5 %, 5 Vdc +5 %/-3 %, and 3.3 Vdc +5 %/-3 % for the subsystem logic, and 15 V ±5 % to power car communications panels.

The power supply CCA also includes two 74 V digital inputs for the CCU location ID strapping and one 74 V digital Input/Output (I/O) for the PA control trainline interface. Isolated switching DC-DC converters are provided.
The system power consumption for each output is presented in the following table.

hazard.hazard-desc: (1) 10 V = 0.5 A transmit peak, 0.250 A idle
(2) 3.3 V = 2.665 A boot-up surge, 1.265 A nominal

section.para: The input power is limited to 65 W under normal operating conditions. An inrush current limiter is provided, which limits inrush current to 3 A maximum.
The CCU power supply CCA requires a two-inch wide slot in the card cage, and is labelled 1, 14 POWER CCA.
The Low Voltage Distribution Network +74 Vdc and 74 Vdc return signals are returned back to the low voltage distribution network connector, for wiring to the PTE circular connector.
The power supply CCA is powered by the low voltage distribution network and operates normally at input voltages in the range of 46 Vdc to 85 Vdc.

The power supply CCA starts up as the input voltage rises above 46 Vdc +0 V/-2 V, and the hysteresis between startup and shutdown is 2 Vdc minimum. The CCU power supply CCA cannot be damaged by the continuous application of voltages below 46 Vdc, and so are other CCU CCAs.
The power supply CCA includes transient protection and reverse polarity protection, as required in IEC 60571.

The transient protection circuit is capable of absorbing an 80 W/s transient. To meet this requirement, the power supply CCA has been tested in accordance with IEC 61000-4-5, level 4, except that the line-to-line test voltage is 4 kV ±10 percent. The source impedance for the test is 2Ω.
A diode is provided for protection against the application of reverse voltage. The reverse protection diode has a breakdown rating of 1,000 V. The inrush limiter transistor breakdown rating is 400 V.
The DC-DC converters are protected against short-circuits.
The 15 V output cannot be damaged by the continuous application of 85 Vdc (either polarity) to the output connections.
Electrical isolation from the low voltage distribution network to any power supply CCA output, to chassis ground, and from chassis ground to any power supply CCA output is 1,148 Vac, minimum.
The low voltage distribution network monitor circuit is used to control the PAA power supply start-up and shutdown.

Circuitry is provided to monitor the low voltage distribution network input voltage. If the input voltage is greater than 44 Vdc, the voltage OK signals with its associated Light Emitting Diode (LED) is set. If the input voltage is between 43 Vdc and 44 Vdc, the low voltage signals and its associated LED is set and the CCU is operational. If the input voltage is below 43 Vdc, then the advance power lost signal is set and is read by the CCU application.
There is a lamp test input to the PAA power supply. All associated LEDs are on while the lamp test input is set.

The CCU power supply maintains a charge sufficient to provide 100 ms additional CCU operating time following the detection of Low Voltage Distribution Network power loss. An interrupt is set to advise the CPU CCA and allows the CCU application to perform a complete shutdown operation without affecting on-board files and permit a safe start-up when re-energized. Power hold-up is not required for the 15 V supply.
Circuitry is provided to monitor the output of the 15 V supply. This 15 V supply monitor is optically isolated from the CCU logic. On the CCU backplane, the 15 V signal is connected to the LON CCA.

Optically isolated circuitry monitors the two 74 V digital inputs for CCU location ID strapping and to control one 74 V digital I/O for PA control trainline interface. The 74 V digital I/O circuit has the same level of protection as the power input of the low voltage distribution network.

section.title: CPU MPC8250 CCA
section.para: The CPU MPC8250 CCA is labelled CPU MPC8250 CCA.
One Motorola MPC8250 embedded processor, which is PowerPC-compatible, is intended for low-power communications applications, and it includes common functional blocks as follows:

list-item.para: Synchronous Dynamic Random Access Memory (SDRAM) controller
Joint Test Access Group / Common On-chip Processor controller

section.para: One 4 MB x 16 flash Programmable Read-Only Memory (PROM) is provided. It provides a total of 8 MB of storage for the board support package. The flash PROMs are programmable under software control, through the MPC8250 Joint Test Access Group / Common On-chip Processor port. The CCA is designed to accept a larger flash PROM on the same footprint, for future designs where additional flash may be needed.
The CPU CCA has 128 MB of RAM. The design of the CCA allows a future upgrade of the CCA to 256 MB of DRAM without requiring modification of the bare Printed Circuit Board (PCB).
The CPU MPC8250 CCA supports the QNX Neutrino Real-Time Operating System (RTOS).
The backplane bus is a simple eight-bit PowerPC compatible I/O bus.

Low voltage detectors cause a full subsystem hardware reset if the 5 Vdc drops below 4.5 Vdc, or if the 3.3 Vdc drops below 3 Vdc. A momentary pushbutton switch (mounted on the front of the CCA and internally accessible) manually resets the subsystem.

A watchdog timer is implemented. The CPU has to update the watchdog timer every five seconds or less to prevent a watchdog reset event. The watchdog causes a full subsystem hardware reset to occur, equivalent to a power-on reset. The watchdog is disabled by default, and enabled under software control and implemented in the CPLD.

Logic indicates the overall health of the subsystem. This logic flashes the HEALTH LED on the indicator CCA at a 1 Hz rate. The subsystem is considered to be healthy if the following conditions are met:

list-item.para: The subsystem is not in reset.
The watchdog timer is running (not expired).

section.para: The HEALTH LED can be disabled under software control, so that the CPU can indicate an unhealthy condition based on software built-in self-test results.

One type 1 compact flash socket is provided, with shock-proof and vibration-proof mounting. The compact flash interfaces in either PC AT attachment Interface (ANSI standard X3.221-1994) or true Integrated Drive Electronics (IDE) mode. The mode selection is controlled by a resistor jumper on the CCA.

The internal real-time clock is provided by the QNX operating system. The clock’s resolution is 1 second. This clock uses the CPU timer, which receives its time base from an 8.192 MHz oscillator with an accuracy of 50 PPM. No adjustments for delays will be possible.

section.title: PCMCIA Card CCA
section.para: The PC card CCA provides one 16-bit PC card LV socket compliant with PC card standard, PCMCIA/Japan Electronics and Information Technology Industries Association (JEITA) 0401-001-1500 electrical specification, section 4. Cold insertion is supported, as is support of true IDE compatible PC cards.

The mechanical form-factor of the CCA allows the socket to protrude from the front of the CCA, so that a PC card can be inserted through a slot in the front of the CCU enclosure. This eliminates the need to open the CCU for PC card insertion and extraction.
One 16-bit PC card LV connector compliant with PC card standard is provided, compatible with types I and II PC cards (PCMCIA compatible), and supports low-voltage cards.

section.title: CCU Indicator CCA
section.para: The CCU indicator CCA provides front panel indication of power and health. Also, SERVICE switches and LED are provided for the Neuron chips. For details on indicators and switches, refer to BOM00764.
The CCU indicator CCA mounts on the inside of the front panel. The CCU indicator CCA is labelled CCU INDICATOR CCA.

section.title: LON CCA
section.para: The LON CCA is labelled LON CCA. The supply voltage for all components on the LON CCA is 5 ±0.25 Vdc, 10 ±0.5 Vdc, or 3.3 ±0.3 Vdc.
The LON CCA PLT-10A channel can be configured for Microprocessor Interface Program / Dual Port System. One PLT-10A interface is provided.
The PLT-10A line interface circuit is implemented in accordance with the LonWorks PLT-10A power line transceiver module user’s guide. One 10 MHz crystal is provided.

The LON CCA FTT-10A channel complies with the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) standard for communications protocol aboard trains. The FTT-10A channel can be configured for Microprocessor Interface Program/ Dual Port System.
An Echelon FTT-10A transceiver is provided, with a network bit rate of 78,125 bits per second. LonMark compliance is achieved, except as noted in the following:

list-item.para: Each LON interface requires an EMI filter and DC blocking circuit. This is a collection of passive components and diodes.

The core of the LON interface is a Neuron 3150 chip, one for each channel. This processor supports the EIA-709.1 (LonTalk) protocol. It has an external address/data bus. One Toshiba Neuron 3150 chip is provided for each LON channel, with clock frequency of 10 MHz.
A 1 MB flash PROM is provided for each LON channel; with 32 Kb of this PROM usable.

The flash PROM is also accessible by the host CPU through the backplane. Address and data multiplexers will be provided to implement this feature. This hardware is needed so that the Neuron chip firmware can be upgraded through the PTE port.

section.para: The LON CCA comprises an 8 Kb dual-ported Static Random Access Memory (SRAM) for each LON channel. A portion of this DPRAM can be used as general-purpose SRAM for network variable buffers. The second DPRAM port is accessible by the host CPU through the backplane.

The LON CCA has one RS-232 interface, which is electrically isolated from the rest of the CCA. Optical isolators provides signal isolation. An optical isolator provides an isolated power health signal for the RS-232 port. The following signals are supported:

list-item.para: Data Terminal Ready (DTR), Data Set Ready (DSR)

section.para: Each RS-232 signal line is protected with resettable polyswitch fuses (power temperature control thermistors), transzorbs, and diodes.

One channel of a 16C552 Universal Asynchronous Receiver-Transmitter (UART) supports the RS-232 interface and its handshake signals includes as a minimum the RTS and CTS. The unused UART handshake signal Data Carrier Detect (DCD) input is wired to signal DSR

A J1708 interface is provided, which is electrically isolated from the rest of the CCA. Optical isolators provide signal isolation. An optical isolator provides an isolated power health signal for the J1708 port. Each J1708 signal line is protected with resettable polyswitch fuses (power temperature control thermistors), transzorbs, and diodes.
One channel of a 16C552 UART is provided to support the J1708 interface. The unused UART handshake signal inputs is wired as follows:

list-item.para: DSR is wired to logic ground (asserted).
DCD is wired to logic ground (asserted).

section.title: WorldFIP CCA
section.para: The WorldFIP CCA allows communications of digitized PA and IC audio over the trainline. To support this, the WorldFIP CCA incorporates a redundant 1 Mb/s trainline interface, interoperable with the ALSTOM reconfigurable WorldFIP physical layer.
The WorldFIP CCA is under the control of the CPU MPC8250 CF CCA, which is responsible for management of all WorldFIP message data.
The bare PCB size is 9 in. high (6U) and 9.0 in. long. The WorldFIP CCA is labelled WORLDFIP CCA.
The supply voltage for all components on the WorldFIP CCA is 5 ±0.25 Vdc and 3.3 ±0.3 Vdc.

The 1 Mb/s WorldFIP interface is implemented by using a FULLFIP2 controller, an FPGA, four FIELDRIVE transceivers, and four FIELDTR isolation transformers. Relays allow bypassing the WorldFIP CCA when it is not operational. Fritting circuitry are provided.
One FULLFIP2 controller is provided in an MQFP100 package.
The WorldFIP CCA comprises 256 Kb x 16 SRAM. The FIPCODE executes from this SRAM. The FIPCODE is programmed into the SRAM through the CPU MPC8250 CF CCA.
The WorldFIP line interface consist of the following elements:

list-item.para: One FPGA to implement repeater and signature logic

section.para: Four Double Pole-Double Throw (DPDT) bypass relays are provided. These will electrically isolate the WordFIP CCA from the WorldFIP networks when the CCU does not have power, when the CCU is reset, or when the CPLD has not been configured to enable the WorldFIP CCA line interfaces. The bypass is removed under software control. One bypass relay is provided for each WorldFIP interface, and each relay is individually software-controllable.

Two galvanically-isolated fritting sources are provided. The fritting sources are controlled by the CPLD. Two galvanically isolated fritting loads are provided. The fritting sources are monitored by the CPLD.

section.title: ACB CCA
section.para: The ACB CCA which includes the ACB DSP Mezzanine CCA are responsible for supporting audio interfaces for IC, PA, PAA and for routing all car-level audio signals. Both automated messages (outgoing) and PA message recording (incoming) are supported. It also provides interface to audio Trainline (T/L) and PA T/L. It implements the CCU location ID strapping decoding for the power supply CCA, and provides noise level inputs for the AOLA.

The Digital Signal Processor (DSP) is capable of handling two 64 Kbps International Telecommunication Union (ITU) G.722 channels simultaneously. All digital audio is compressed by using the ITU G.722 algorithm for storage (PA recording) and transmission to or from the WorldFIP network. Pre-recorded audio of the voice database is also stored with the G.722 format on the CPU CCA flash memory. An analog device ADSP-BF533SBBZ500 DSP is used to encode and decode all CODEC audio packets in the ITU G.722 format.
Dual-ported Random Access Memory (DPRAM) is provided to allow the CCU application to interface with the DSP.
A SRAM (64 Mb x 16 SDRAM) is used for DSP configurations.

A 4 Mb flash memory is provided to store the DSP application. The application will reside in the DSP flash memory and on the CPU CCA flash memory (part of the CCU Software Configuration Item (SCI)). At boot-up, the CCU application loads the DSP application in the DSP flash memory if a Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC) error is encountered.
The audio Line Interface Units (LIU) is galvanically isolated. Each LIU is differential and has a nominal impedance of 600 Ω.
The following analog interfaces are provided:

list-item.para: Five bidirectional audio interfaces (three CCP, one PEI, and one CCCP)
Two bidirectional audio trainline interfaces (IC and PA).

section.para: The PA System includes the microphones, amplifiers, speakers, and associated wiring and other circuits. The PA System has the following performance characteristics in operation.

list-item.para: Frequency response is ±3 dB minimum from 80 to 8,000 Hz
Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) at 1kHz is as follows:
Microphone input (Sound Pressure Level (SPL)) to output (audio electrical signal): Less than 1 percent
Speaker input (audio electric signal) to output (SPL): Less than 1 percent
PA system from Microphone electrical input to speaker electrical output: Less than 1 percent.
Signal to Noise Ratio: Less than 100:1.

section.para: The PA control trainline are sensed and controlled by the ACB CCA. The sense input and control output are galvanically isolated from the CCU. The ACB latches the CCU location ID strapping, whereas the power supply CCA provides the actual 74 Vdc isolated inputs circuitry.
A 836 multi-channel CODEC is used for analog to digital and digital to analog conversion.
Integrated circuit analog switch arrays are used to multiplex and route signals between the LIUs and the two CODECs, as required. The switch arrays are under the control of the CPU MPC8250 CCA.

section.title: PAA/Door Chime
section.para: The PAA is completely solid state and is housed in the CCU. The PAA amplifies the analog audio signal from the ACB CCA and distributes it to the PA speaker systems through a 70.7 V output transformer.
The amplifier operates continuously with full output, at the rated input voltage, without damage to the components.

section.title: Audio Level Requirements
section.para: A minimum compression range is provided by the 18 dB microphone pre-amplifier with a maximum output level variation of 2 dB at the compressor output. The amplifier is designed such that the audio outputs to the trainlines and speakers have a consistent level when the operator’s mouth is between 2 and 12 inches from the microphone. The line amplifier, through the ACB CCA, is capable of delivering a minimum of +20 dBm into an impedance of 200 to 600 Ω with less than 1 percent total harmonic distortion. The electronics have a THD less than 1 percent measured, from microphone input to speaker output.

section.title: Door Chime Features
section.para: Four independent 1 W door chime audio outputs are added to the PAA for the interior speakers and two 16 W audio outputs for the exterior speakers. Four audio outputs are connected to the interior speakers and two to the exterior speakers. Each output is controlled directly by the door controller of its zone through discrete isolated inputs (low voltage distribution network level) so the door chime is heard when a door chime request is present for each zone. Four audio outputs are implemented to drive the interior speakers and two to drive the exterior speakers. The door chime on the interior speakers is mixed with the other audio announcements and complies with the same audio quality requirement as a standalone PA announcement. The door chime on the exterior speakers play the door chime only. The following table identifies the input to output relationship and speakers connections.

table.title: Door Chime Input to Output Relationship

section.para: The pulsed signal of 50 percent duty cycle is generated by a hardware sound generator circuit playing back pre-defined door chime files. A quantity of ten door chime files allow maintenance crew to select, using the PTE, the desired pre-defined periods covering a span of 0.5 to 1.5 seconds. The files are factory programmed in the flash memory.

The volume of each chime output is adjustable independently of the other audio levels with a range of 75 to 95 dB at 1 meter from the PA/Door Chime speakers installed inside the car. The level adjustment is done using the PTE.

The door chime output is directly controlled by the hardware input signal in order to reduce the activation delay to a minimum. All door chime audio outputs originate from the same CCU audio source so all door chime interior and exterior speakers will play a synchronized door chime (50 percent duty cycle on and off at the same time).

Each door chime CCU speaker output will have the capability to independently mute by software a PA announcement without affecting the ongoing door chime. This feature is required to prevent PA feedback in the CCP.

section.title: PAA Amplifier CCA
section.para: The audio power amplifiers are made of three high-efficiency class D audio power amplifiers with very low dissipation. A single 25 W amplifier is implemented for the PAA main output and four 10 W amplifiers for the door chime output for the interior PA speakers and two 16 W amplifiers for the door chime output for the exterior PA speakers. The power amplifier integrated circuit is a dual channel (stereo) device that can be connected in single-ended or in bridge-tied load configuration. This feature is used to produce the main output of the PAA, through one bridge-tied load device, and the six-door chime outputs, through two single-ended devices.
The power amplifier features are the following:

list-item.para: No switch-on nor switch-off plop noise
Short-circuit-proof across the load and to the supply lines

section.title: PAA Transformer Assembly
section.para: All outputs are fed through a 70 V line distribution amplifier. The main output transformer is rated to 25 W nominal and the door chime output transformers are rated to 10 W for the interior outputs (4x) and 16 W for the exterior outputs (2x).
The PAA transformer CCA provides transient protection on the PAA speaker output lines.

section.title: PAA Controller CCA
section.para: Potentiometers are used to adjust the gain of each equalizer band to obtain the desired frequency response. The set point of each potentiometer is then measured and fixed resistors are installed in the production PAA units in order to reproduce the same frequency response
The center frequencies of the three bands of the equalizer are 250 Hz, 1000 Hz, and 3500 Hz. Each band has a Q factor of 1.5 and an adjustable gain of ±12 dB.
The J1708 communication circuit is the same as for the communication panels.
The digital potentiometers are used to allow the CCU software to control audio levels from 0 to 100 percent of the output signal.
A flash memory of a minimum of 128 KB is used to store ten digital audio chime files. Each file is preset for the period interval identified in Table . All digital audio files are factory-programmed.
The digital-to-analog converter chime allows a minimum of 16 K samples per seconds, with a resolution of 12 bits.

Six 74 Vdc hardware inputs on the CCU activate the corresponding PA/door chime speaker outputs. Each input is a hardware line coming from the DCU in the zone requesting a door chime. The chime starts upon the presence of 74 Vdc on the input and stops on the absence of signal (0 V). The four inputs are galvanically isolated with optical couplers on the PAA power supply CCA and are limited to 0.4 A at 74 Vdc.

section.title: PAA Power Supply CCA
section.para: The PAA power supply CCA converts the Low Voltage Distribution Network (74 Vdc nominal) power to 5 Vdc and 3.3 Vdc for the PAA logic and audio input circuits, and to ±25 V for the power amplifier section.
The PAA power supply CCA is based on isolated switching DC-DC converters.
The normal PAA power consumption for each output is expected to be as follows:
The nominal input power does not exceed 90 W under normal operating conditions. An inrush current limiter is provided, limiting inrush current to 3 A maximum.

The PAA power supply is powered by the Low Voltage Distribution Network, and operates normally at input voltages in the range of 46 to 85 Vdc. The PAA power supply starts as the input voltage rises above 46 Vdc +0 V/-2 V, and the hysteresis between startup and shutdown is 2 Vdc minimum. The PAA power supply CCA cannot be damaged by the continuous application of voltages below 46 Vdc.
The PAA power supply includes transient protection and reverse polarity protection as required by IEC 60571.

The transient protection circuit is capable of absorbing an 80 W/s transient. To meet this requirement, the 6U power (74 V) CCA is tested in accordance with IEC 61000-4-5, level 4, except that the line-to-line test voltage is 4 kV ±10 percent. The source impedance for the test is 2Ω.
A diode is provided for protection against the application of reverse voltage. The reverse protection diode has a breakdown rating of 1000 V. The inrush limiter transistor breakdown rating is 400 V.

Electrical isolation from the Low Voltage Distribution Network to the PAA power supply output is 1,148 VAC minimum. There is appropriate circuitry to avoid charge cumulation between the 74 Vdc and the DC-DC converters.
The electrical isolation from the Low Voltage Distribution Network to chassis ground is 1,148 Vac minimum. The electrical isolation from the chassis ground to any PAA output is 1,148 Vac minimum.

section.title: Cab Communication Control Panel
section.para: Figure illustrates the Cab Communication Control Panel (CCCP) unit block diagram.

The CCCP is operative only when the NJ Transit standard coach key is inserted into the master key switch of the cab master door controller panel, or when the reverser handle is inserted into the master controller in the operating cab.

When the microphone is activated, the CCU software mutes all end vestibule public address speakers to prevent audio feedback. A contact relay in the panel allows muting PA speakers connected on the PAA main audio line. An array of three microphones is used in the CCCP.
The CCCP communication panel CCA includes a J1708 serial control, an automatic gain control circuit, a speaker amplifier, and a microphone pre-amplifier.

section.title: Communication Control Panel
section.para: Figure illustrates the Communication Control Panel (CCP) unit block diagram.

An array of three microphones is used in the CCP to ensure low feedback and attenuate background noise. The signal from the three microphones are processed to maximize the array’s directivity by summing all three signals. This summation, combined with proper microphone position, attenuates out-of-phase signals (sound coming from the side), and amplifies only in-phase signals (sound coming from a source directly in front of the CCP).

When the microphone is activated, the CCU software mutes the PA speakers closest to the panel to prevent audio feedback. The muting is under software control. A contact relay in the panel allows muting PA speakers connected on the PAA main audio line. The key switch is an opto-mechanical device identifying the uniqueness of the standard key.

All CCP units are physically identical but, under control of the Communication Control Unit (CCU), CCP1 (cab back wall) has a specific behavior: When the standard coach key is inserted into the master key switch of the cab master door controller panel, or when the reverser handle is inserted into the operating cab’s master controller, that cab’s CCP1 is set to intercom monitoring mode (that is, speaker-only mode).
The CCP communication panel CCA includes a J1708 serial control, an automatic gain control circuit, a speaker amplifier, and a microphone pre-amplifier.

section.title: Passenger Emergency Intercom Panels
section.para: Figure illustrates the Passenger Emergency Intercom (PEI) unit block diagram.
The PEI communication panel CCA includes a J1708 serial control, an automatic gain control circuit, a speaker amplifier, and a microphone pre-amplifier.
The PEI provides a discrete input connected to the External Push-to-call (EPTC) pushbutton, a normally closed pushbutton. EPTC is a remote for the PEI5 (toilet) PUSH TO CALL pushbutton.

section.title: PA Speaker, Transformer, and Noise Sensing Microphones
section.para: The PA speakers have two configurations:

list-item.para: With AOLA (for PA announcement volume adjustment, using noise sensing microphones)

section.para: Both configurations have the following specifications:

list-item.para: Frequency response: ±3 dB minimum from 80 Hz to 8.000 Hz
Signal to noise ratio: Less than 100:1.

section.para: The enclosures are constructed to prevent mechanical resonance and vibration to occur.

The speakers are of the direct radiating, permanent magnet field type capable of handling up to 10 W of audio power, with an outside diameter of 6 in. (nominal), and an impedance of 8 Ω. The speakers are phased so that when the primary is connected to the distribution line according to labelling, all speaker cones are moving in the same direction at the same time. The nominal axial sensitivity is at least 92 dB at four feet with one-W input. The speakers have a wide dispersion characteristic and are moisture-resistant. All ferrous metal parts are made rust-resistant by plating.

The transformer is a 70 V line matching transformer with four, two, and one Watt power taps. The transformer-end of the lead is arranged to permit connection or reconnection of the conductors to any taps. The secondary of the transformer properly matches the voice coil of the speaker. The primary of the matching transformer is connected to the speaker distribution wires connected in parallel with uniform polarity to the PAA/door chime audio output CCA. The transformer is moisture resistant. All ferrous metal parts are made rust resistant by plating.

A noise sensing microphone is installed in four PA speakers to implement for AOLA function. These PA speakers are located in the ceiling of the car in the following areas: one in each mid-level section, one in the lower level, and one in the upper level. These locations represent areas of the car where noise levels are considered very different.

The sensing microphone signals provide the required input stimulus to the AOLA function. The AOLA function automatically adjusts the PA speaker audio output level 10 dB above the calculated noise level up to a level of 90 dB. The calculated noise level is an average value of each sensing microphones, which are weighted to compensate for sonorous sections of the car. Each weight values can be configured by the PTE. The compensation will be established when car noise data are provided. The noise sensing microphones are sampled at a rate of 1 Hz between PA announcements for an integration period of 5 seconds. The last five samples are used to establish the PAA PA speaker output level. For example, if a manual announcement is made two seconds after an automatic announcement, the three samples before the automatic announcement and the two samples after are used to compute the noise level in the car. Each sample level is translated in a logarithmic scale to reduce the signal dynamic range. The logarithmic signal is modulated in PWM and sent to the ACB CCA. The signal is then demodulated, weighted, and stored for noise level calculation. The noise level calculation is the average level of all four weighted values of the last five samples.

section.title: VHF Train Radio
section.para: The VHF Radio Unit is capable of operating on all frequencies in the 148-174 MHz band at a maximum power output of 45 W. Up to 256 channels can be programmed, among which 99 are American Association of Railroad (AAR) channels.
The radio is interchangeable with the Comet IV and Comet V Motorola radios. The radio is energized by the LVPS through its own circuit breaker. The radio is operative from 45 to 90 Vdc.

The train radio communication mode is the highest priority in the event of a communication system failure. The CCCP directly connects the microphone, pushbutton, speaker, and any other required components to the radio in such an event.
Radio circuitry includes a transmitter time-out-timer feature to prevent inadvertent lockout of the transmitter.
Transient filter protections are designed as an integral part of the radio and provides adequate protection from transients of the type encountered in commuter car and locomotive applications.
The radio’s channel selection and operating modes are programmable by a laptop computer (IBM compatible). Radio disassembly is not required to connect the computer to the radio unit for programming.
The radio meets the AAR design criteria.

The radio is remotely controlled from the CCCP, however, the radio is operative even when the CCU is not functional. This avoids the CCU application to be part of radio control and possibly lock the radio when CCU application problem occurs.
The radio is set up to transmit and receive on the 10 channels listed in Table .

section.title: Internal Architecture
section.para: The internal architecture of each sign is depicted in Figure . Each sign is based on the same internal architecture. A 74 Vdc power supply is provided and converted down to the appropriate voltage required by the internal electronic components. A LonWorks controller interfaces with the external LonWorks network. The controller manages the messages displayed on the LCD tiles. Depending on the type of signs, 8 or 15 LCD tile sets are installed into the signs. All LCD PCB drivers are daisy-chained to one another for passing of information: the LON controller pushes the message composition to the LCD tiles over TTL.

The subsystem configuration is based on displays with individual power supply and LON CPU interface controller. With this arrangement, each sign can display independent information. For diagnostic purposes, the last tile is linked with the LON controller. In this way, it is possible to see whether the information has gone through all the LCD tiles without corruption.

All the electronic signs are based on an Echelon FT3150 processor, which interfaces with the Lonworks network, manages the display portion and takes care of logging faults and information. This FT3150-P20 combined with an Echelon FT-X1 communication transformer is used for the LON interface.

The LON Controller features static memory used to store non-volatile information e.g. fonts and special characters, logs and configuration file. The static memory does not need to be battery backed. A Flash memory is exclusive to the code and RAM is used for temporary data.

A temperature sensor is used to monitor the internal temperature and reduce the LED backlight intensity in case of high temperatures, to extend the life span of the LCD tiles (which are sensitive to heat). Each LCD character is a 105-segment mosaic that reproduces any character from A to Z (upper case or lower case) and numbers from 0 to 9.

section.title: System Initialization
section.para: This is the first mode of operation of each display in the system at power-up. Once all physical connections are established and a sign is powered on, it steps through a boot sequence that includes a self-test. If necessary, the sign accepts to be configured by the MCU.
The power-on self-test includes the following checks:

list-item.para: A checksum calculation test for font file.
A checksum calculation test for configuration file.

A verification of the data path internal to the sign verifies that the characters sent to display come back to the controller without error. This ensures that the electronic data line is not corrupted.

A verification of the temperature sensor inside the sign. When temperature is detected high, the backlight intensity is reduced and an event is triggered. This increases the lifetime of the LCD modules and the LED backlight.

section.para: The configuration is location-dependent (including left side/right side). If after configuration the sign is moved to a different location, the sign reverts to unconfigured state and enters the boot sequence.

Because the same software runs on all signs, which are similar in terms of functionality except for number of characters displayed, the software recognizes on which type of sign it is executing. The sign identifies itself by reading from the connector’s 4-bit address. If the connection is unavailable, as when the sign is being debugged on a BTE, the sign will differentiate its type (8 or 15 characters) by reading from an internal jumper.

section.title: System Operation In Normal Mode
section.para: This mode of operation follows the successful completion of Initialization Mode. In this mode, the CCU can transmit data, which signs receive and process. For example, next station information can be sent to the Interior Message Signs. In addition, any continual diagnostic data requests by the MCU can now be transmitted by the signs.

Self-diagnostics are continuously run. To increase the lifetime of the LCD tiles and the LED backlight, temperature sensors cause the backlighting intensity to be reduced (degraded mode) and an event to be triggered when internal temperature falls outside limits. Hardware self-tests and display tests can also be called on demand.

section.title: System Operation In Degraded Mode
section.para: This mode of operation is initiated when the internal temperature rises above (or falls below) a set point in the upper part (or lower part) of the operating range specified. The signs will operate in degraded mode (reduced LED intensity) at high temperature. If the temperature exceeds a specified upper limit the LED backlight will automatically be turned off. If the temperature goes below the lower thresholds, the LCD Tiles are turned off, and the LED backlight stays on to warm up the sign. In addition, the signs incorporate logic to ensure that the LED panel brightness does not flicker when the ambient temperature is near the set point or the cutoff temperature.
Note that the LCD tiles are turned off when temperature falls below -10 °C and are turned back on only when the temperature climbs back to -5 °C.

section.title: System Operation In Maintenance Mode
section.para: This mode of operation is initiated by connecting the PTE laptop to the CCU or the DCN. Maintenance mode allows the operator to perform diagnostic tests to isolate faulty or defective signs. This mode also allows the operator to record and report all faults and failures. The maintenance mode operation are transparent to normal mode operation, except for visual tests that display test sequence of characters, which override any messages sent by the CCU. Once maintenance mode is terminated the sign will return to displaying the message sent by the CCU.

section.title: System Operation In Load Shed Mode
section.para: Load shed mode is managed by two bits of the car status, plus an internal timer. Each sign’s backlight is turned off in order to reduce the load on the battery system. However, in this mode, the signs keep on receiving and displaying messages.

section.title: Network Interface
section.para: All signs are considered as slaves over the network. Each individual sign communicates with other nodes via a LonWorks network.

The signs receive messages to display as a text strings from the CCU. The signs exchange diagnostic and status information with the CLDS through network variables. Portable Test Equipment (PTE) allows system troubleshooting, log retrieval and viewing, self-tests on demand, configuration and font update via file upload, and neuron-based software upgrade.

section.title: Message Application Process
section.para: The Neuron Chip handles all signs operations. A process transforms string messages received from the CCU to bit strings representing characters to be displayed on the LCD sign. Strings shorter than the maximum possible number of displayable characters are automatically centered. Strings longer than the maximum number of displayable characters are displayed in multiple pages, one page at a time.

Signs accept the standard 8-bit ASCII codes (95 characters from 0x20 to 0x7F), including upper and lower case letters, digits from 0 to 9 and basic symbols (!”/$%?&*( )+,-.:;<>[ ]#). Memory is reserved for an extra set of 127 special characters.
